/10-strategies-for-facebook-ads-that-con.title: 10 Strategies for Facebook ads that Convert- Marketing Magic Tips
/10-strategies-for-facebook-ads-that-con.description: Explore successful strategies for creating Facebook ads that yield results.
/10-strategies-for-facebook-ads-that-con.h1: 10 Strategies for Facebook ads that Convert- Marketing Magic Tips
/10-strategies-for-facebook-ads-that-con.h4: in Advice, Articles, Blog, Business tips, Entrepreneurs, facebook marketing, Marketing Magic Tip, Pay per click, Small Business, Social media marketing, Startups
/10-strategies-for-facebook-ads-that-con.p: You’d have to be living in a bunker deep underground to have failed to realise that Facebook Ads is growing in popularity for businesses. Marketing on the social media platform is only going to increase because it looks easy to find clients using Facebook Ads. That is why 93% of marketers use Facebook to advertise. Anyone who has done Facebook ads knows that it is easy to spend a tonne of your hard-earned cash and not get the results you want or expect. I have been there, so I know how frustrating that feels especially as we see and read about others who have built their business on Facebook ads alone. This post is a guide to create compelling ads that will have people raving to buy from you or work with you? If you want to build your business by using Facebook Ads (even if you suck at them), then this blog is for you. I will tell share the strategies I use to get thousands of warm leads and customers for my clients (all small businesses). Every business needs a stable pipeline of prospective clients that are in the process of buying your products or service. Marketing and advertising is the way to not only find these ‘prospects’ (aka leads) but to also engage and nurture them until they are ready to buy. The average UK SME owner will be putting around 16% of their 2018/19 budget into marketing, according to a study by performance marketing network Affilinet. Furthermore, Social media (22%) came out on top of the list marketing elements that small business leaders will be looking to prioritise in the coming year. It follows that marketing is central to any business and most of us will try to take advantage of any glimmer of light that may make our lives easie, while bringing the results we want. Facebook advertising Facebook makes its profits in two main ways: by collecting as much data as possible from us and by controlling what we pay for access to that data. The figures tell the real story: Facebook has 1.1 billion daily users, so pretty much everyone from the grannies to business owners and their children is on Facebook. Added to that Facebook has built their business on collecting data from their users (us) that we willingly give them. They use the information to “personalise” the platform for companies who pay to advertise there. Facebook has become the go-to platform to target your ideal clients all in one place. It turns out that some of the information Facebook has been using to target ads has not been provided to the site at all, explicitly or otherwise. This has been dubbed “shadow information”, and includes contact details shared with the platform by another user, such as those provided for the “find friends” function (Marketing Tech). Digital rights campaigner Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) has even called the social network “deceptive and invasive” as a result of how they use people’s data, sometimes without us knowing or without us giving consent. Whatever the ethical and moral arguments about Facebook’s data sources and practices, their detailed targeting information is precisely what makes Facebook ads so useful for small businesses – we can target the right people with the right message so that they are more likely to buy our product or service. Google vs Facebook Some may ask: isn’t Google Ads bigger than Facebook ads? The simple answer is ‘yes’. Google is a bigger advertising platform than Facebook because it generates higher ad revenues. Google’s $84.69bn ad revenue compared to Facebook’s $33.84bn revenue in the last year proves the fact. More importantly for businesses looking for the right advertising medium, Facebook ads and Google Ads are fundamentally different: Google is best for things that people are actively searching for hence it is best described as search marketing. Facebook is heaven for things that people may not know they are looking for. So it fits the concept of discovery marketing. Furthermore, Google search Ads are mostly text-based with around 30 characters available to describe your product or services whereas Facebook allows more words and most importantly, engaging photos and videos. For marketers, it is not a matter of which ads platform is better as they are distinctly different. However, there are predictions that within two years, Facebook and Google will be the only good advertising platforms worth spending your money on as a small business – unless you can afford the high costs of offline advertising on radio or television. Now that you are sold on the rationale for Facebook ads, let us look at what business do, where many go wrong and how to sell more...
/10-strategies-for-facebook-ads-that-con.author: EnyOsung

/the-importance-of-teams-why-the-best-le.title: The Importance of Teams, Why the Best Leaders Cultivate Them & Making Teams Work
/the-importance-of-teams-why-the-best-le.description: Discover the importance of teams and how effective leaders cultivate them for success. Learn actionable strategies to make teams work efficiently and deliver transformative results. Explore the concept of psychologically safe environments and their impact on team performance. Be inspired by the power of teamwork and learn how leaders can drive collaboration, communication, and unity within their teams.
/the-importance-of-teams-why-the-best-le.h1: The Importance of Teams, Why the Best Leaders Cultivate Them & Making Teams Work
/the-importance-of-teams-why-the-best-le.p: Note: Mark Suster originally published the majority of this post on April 17, 2016. I am reposting most of it here with my edits and additions because the content is relevant to most of our small businesses. Getting our teams to work efficiently and more is challenging. When doing teamwork properly, the results are transformative and much more than the sum of the individual parts. Never one to just raise a topic, I have added extensively to the original to give actionable strategies to make teams work efficiently to deliver results. I was watching my favorite show on TV this morning — GPS (Global Public Square) with Fareed Zakaria. It is a hugely compelling show because Zakaria covers world issues that will affect all of us in ways that are accessible and with frameworks for processing disparate information. He brings knowledgeable experts from varying points of view but never books anybody that engages in yelling matches. The show has become my best curator of which books to read (including my favorite of last year, The Accidental Superpower) and my go-to for understanding geopolitics of Russia, Iran, Pakistan, China, India, and of course the US. But they also take on issues in science, technology, and management. Essentially it’s a replacement for reading The Economist every week (which I would do if I could find more time!). Example from this morning was a quick discussion on the 'Brexit' and whether the UK will exit Europe. This morning’s show took on the topic of 'teams' and highlighted research that Julia Rozovsky and Google has conducted called Project Aristotle and profiled in Charles Duhigg’s book Smarter, Faster, Better. I haven’t read the book nor deeply reviewed Project Aristotle but the conversation on this morning’s show really resonated with me. Rozovsky basically said that having studied 180 teams at Google over the past several years and trying to determine what made some teams perform better than others (despite every team being filled with over-achievers who work at Google) one factor stood out more than others: Creating 'psychologically safe environments.' The idea is that teams that allow everybody to speak, allow dissent, encourage safe discussions where it’s ok to be wrong — succeed more. I’m recounting this from having watched the show (I’m sure it will be online within the week), and I’m going to spend some more time reading about Project Aristotle. But the conversation rang very true for me.
/the-importance-of-teams-why-the-best-le.p2: Making Teams work Teams are by definition made up of individuals who have been brought together to achieve particular objectives that they would not be able to reach individually. It would be fantastic if teams started working smoothly from day one. However, this rarely happens as we all know from experience. We have all been in teams where members are in conflict even open warfare, people duplicating roles and tasks, members not being motivated to contribute to the team effort, team members undermining each other, and rebellion against team leaders. The approach and actions of the group’s leader are fundamental to making teams work smoothly. They play a crucial role in every stage of making teams function, from the formation through to evaluation and Here are five key areas for team managers to address in every group situation. 1. Creating an Active Team A good team leader articulates a vision for the future of the team. They fully appreciate the benefits that teamwork brings including reducing isolation, sharing the load, utilizing people’s skills and enhancing motivation. Leaders of successful teams establish clear objectives for the team, based on overall departmental goals. They convey their vision to the team at every opportunity. To set up and manage effective teams, managers need to: - Understand the value of teams at work - Appreciate that diversity in the team is a strength if it’s well managed - Explore techniques for team leadership - Work out team members’ roles and responsibilities - Make a chart so that everyone knows what everyone else should be doing, and communicate it inside and outside the team.
/the-importance-of-teams-why-the-best-le.p3: Managing Teams Think about some of the things that have made teams you have been part of work well – I have no doubt there are many and varied things on your list. Ground rules One often forgotten component that is critical for successful teamwork is setting the ground rules so that every member starts from the same hymn sheet. Unless the team leader provides a good foundation, the team may be a very sociable environment, but it will not be very productive. Here are some of the key elements that comprise ground rules. Direction – Articulate a vision for the future. Establish clear objectives for the team, based on overall departmental goals. Convey your vision to the team at every opportunity. Roles – Work out team members’ roles and responsibilities. Make a chart so that everyone knows what everyone else should be doing, and communicate it inside and outside the team. Targets – Establish the immediate challenges and workload. Set short-term goals – then agree how they will meet these objectives and what support or information you or other members of the team can provide. Structures – Agree reporting structures, routines, and resource requirements. Processes – Explain day-to-day processes, such as approaches to decision-making, problem-solving, and meetings. Performance criteria – Explain how you will judge the team, and the performance standards involved. Contingency plans – Discuss what action you will take if things don’t go according to plan. Team leaders rarely benefit from dictating ground rules to teams of professionals and experts, in particular – the members will just withdraw into their shells or start an open rebellion against the leader and team members as a whole. A collaborative approach in which team members share ideas and propose the ground rules increases the chance of getting buy-in. Management behaviors There is more to team effectiveness than great leadership! Without the commitment and contribution of every member, teams will never be more than a collection of individuals. The team leader’s role includes performing these tasks to involve and manage team members so that everyone can contribute their best. Make time for the team – Spend time with the individual members of the team to allow them to air their concerns about how the process has been handled up to now, and how things will pan out in the future. Value contributions – Explain why individuals’ contributions are significant, and their knowledge and expertise vital to the team’s success. Be open – Gather suggestions on how to make connections and establish healthy relationships. Mistakes happen! – Make it clear that you know mistakes happen, and those problems must be flagged up as soon as possible so that the team can resolve them. Involve the whole team in team plans – Work out which issues may be significant and encourage a collective plan of action from the entire team. Help individual members – Encourage team members to identify how they might best contribute to key areas. Help members understand more fully the different features and requirements of the business as a whole. Encourage team action – Explain to team members how you expect them to work together and invite suggestions on how they will achieve this. Provide opportunities for the team to share and discuss ideas. Tackle conflict head-on – Confront areas of conflict. In doing so, make sure everyone understands why this is important and focus on an approach that will help you resolve the issue.
/the-importance-of-teams-why-the-best-le.author: EnyOsung

/psychological-pricing-strategies-guide-.title: Psychological Pricing Strategies Guide - 9 Secrets to Sell More
/psychological-pricing-strategies-guide-.description: Discover the secrets of psychological pricing strategies and learn how to sell more effectively. This guide provides valuable insights into pricing psychology and its impact on consumer behavior. Explore nine pricing secrets that can influence purchasing decisions, create a perception of value, and maximize sales. Understand the concepts of anchoring, charm pricing, decoy pricing, and other techniques used by successful businesses. Implement these strategies in your small business or startup to optimize pricing and drive profitability. Download the guide and unlock the secrets of psychological pricing to boost your sales.
/psychological-pricing-strategies-guide-.h1: Psychological Pricing Strategies Guide - 9 Secrets to Sell More
/psychological-pricing-strategies-guide-.p: Pricing plays a crucial role in influencing consumer behavior and ultimately driving sales. By understanding the psychological factors that affect how customers perceive prices, businesses can strategically set their prices to increase sales and maximize revenue. In this guide, we will explore nine secrets to leverage psychological pricing strategies and sell more effectively. Charm Pricing: One of the most widely used strategies is charm pricing, which involves setting prices just below a round number. For example, pricing a product at $9.99 instead of $10. This creates the perception of a significantly lower price, even though the difference is minimal. Customers tend to focus on the leftmost digit, associating the price with the lower value. Bundle Pricing: Offering bundled products or services at a discounted price can be an effective strategy. By combining multiple items together and pricing them lower than the sum of their individual prices, customers perceive it as a value deal. This encourages them to make a purchase, as they feel they are getting more for their money. Prestige Pricing: Prestige pricing capitalizes on the notion that higher-priced products are of superior quality. By setting higher prices, businesses create an aura of exclusivity and luxury around their offerings. This strategy appeals to certain customer segments who associate price with status and perceive higher-priced items as more desirable. Anchoring Effect: The anchoring effect refers to the tendency of individuals to rely heavily on the first piece of information they receive when making decisions. By strategically placing a high-priced item next to a lower-priced item, businesses can anchor customers' expectations. This makes the lower-priced item appear more affordable and enticing by comparison. Decoy Pricing: Decoy pricing involves introducing a third option, often referred to as the decoy, to influence customers' decision-making. The decoy is strategically designed to make a particular product seem like the best value. For example, offering a small size option that is priced higher than a larger size, making the larger size appear more cost-effective. Loss Aversion: People tend to place a higher value on avoiding losses than on acquiring gains. Leveraging this psychological bias, businesses can emphasize potential savings or discounts to make customers feel like they are avoiding a loss by purchasing the product. Phrases like 'Save 50%' or 'Limited Time Offer' evoke a sense of urgency and fear of missing out. Odd-Even Pricing: This strategy involves utilizing odd numbers for lower-priced items and even numbers for higher-priced items. Odd numbers are associated with discounts and affordability, while even numbers convey quality and higher value. By aligning the price with customers' perception, businesses can influence their decision-making process. Subscription Pricing: Offering subscription-based pricing can lead to recurring revenue streams and increased customer loyalty. By providing a lower monthly or yearly price compared to individual purchases, businesses create a sense of long-term value and convenience. Customers are more likely to commit to a subscription when they perceive it as a cost-saving option. Price Anchoring: This strategy involves presenting a higher-priced option alongside the main product to make it appear more reasonably priced. By offering tiered pricing or showcasing a premium version of the product, customers are more likely to choose the mid-range option, perceiving it as the best value for their money. By implementing these nine psychological pricing strategies, businesses can tap into the subconscious drivers that influence consumer behavior. Remember, pricing is not merely a number, but a powerful tool to shape perceptions and drive sales. Understanding the psychology behind pricing empowers businesses to sell more effectively and ultimately achieve greater success in the market.
/psychological-pricing-strategies-guide-.p2: Now armed with these secrets, go ahead and apply psychological pricing strategies to enhance the effectiveness of your pricing strategies. Experiment with different approaches and monitor customer responses to determine which techniques work best for your target market.
/psychological-pricing-strategies-guide-.p3: Remember to consider the unique characteristics of your products or services, your competitors' pricing strategies, and the value proposition you offer to customers. Regularly evaluate and adjust your pricing strategy to align with market trends and customer preferences. In addition to implementing these psychological pricing strategies, it's crucial to maintain transparency and ethical business practices. Customers appreciate honesty, so ensure that your pricing accurately reflects the value of your offerings and avoids deceptive tactics. Lastly, don't forget to test and measure the impact of your pricing strategies on your sales and revenue. Keep track of key metrics, such as conversion rates, average order value, and customer feedback, to gauge the effectiveness of your pricing decisions. Use this data to fine-tune your approach and continually optimize your pricing strategy for maximum results.
/psychological-pricing-strategies-guide-.p4: In conclusion, mastering the art of psychological pricing can give your business a competitive edge in the market. By understanding how customers perceive prices and leveraging their psychological biases, you can influence their buying decisions and drive sales. Implement these nine secrets to sell more effectively, and watch as your business flourishes with increased customer engagement, higher conversions, and improved profitability.
/psychological-pricing-strategies-guide-.author: EnyOsung

/making-sure-the-price-is-right.title: Making Sure the Price is Right
/making-sure-the-price-is-right.description: Learn the truth about pricing and discover strategies to set the right price for your business. Understand the psychological factors that influence buyer behavior and make informed pricing decisions.
/making-sure-the-price-is-right.h1: Making Sure the Price is Right
/making-sure-the-price-is-right.p: All businesses have to set prices, but finding the right price can be challenging. This blog post explores the importance of price, dispels common pricing myths, and provides insights into factors that influence buyer behavior. Understanding how price works psychologically empowers businesses to set the right prices and maximize profitability. Learn how to avoid common pricing mistakes and implement effective pricing strategies. I frequently come across small business and start-up clients who seem happy to continue making the same mistakes with pricing over and over again. Here we look at how to make sure your price is right by examining four myths about pricing and reasons you should not believe them. I also suggest factors to focus on to remove barriers to selling as well as things to get right tot make people buy from online businesses.
/making-sure-the-price-is-right.p2: Without a doubt, price matters! Price is often one of the first things prospects look at when researching products and services. Moreover, e-commerce businesses are also competing for trust and increasingly for consumers’ attention. Given the fact that people’s attention spans have gone down from 12 seconds in 2000 to 8 seconds in 2013 (a massive 33% decline), businesses have to do an awesome job of giving people clear value as soon as people see your business To be successful, small businesses must learn the pricing techniques that help to sell more. Here we examine some of the common misconceptions about pricing strategies to make sure the price is right for your business and customers.
/making-sure-the-price-is-right.h6: Myth #1: Everything has an agreed value
/making-sure-the-price-is-right.p3: Many businesses wrongly set prices based on what they think their product is worth. This is often coupled with a belief that customers will be unwilling to pay any more than this inherent price because they agree on the fixed value. Let’s use my love for designer label polo shirts to work out the reality. You see, I am a self-confessed sucker for Moschino, Armani, Versace, Burberry or any other famous fashion house polo shirts and will happily pay upwards of £100 for a black one in my size (I see prefer to keep how big I am to myself). It’s the ease of wearing them and the fact that they go with virtually any outfit that I love. What are these polo shirts actually worth? The logic above says the real price that customers should be willing to pay should be a combination of how much it cost to make, buy and deliver something as well as a small margin on top to make it worthwhile for the retailer. In truth, pricing is rarely this scientific and mathematical. In reality, we all know that it probably cost no more than £5 to manufacture these polo shirts. Yet people like me readily pay the money to own one. The media and fashion houses have really done a number of subtle cues on people like me over the years to get us to value the designer’s label to the point of irrational behaviour (clever marketing, celebrity endorsements and brand reputation are just some of the ways). There is no notion of ‘real’ price when it comes to making the purchase! The polo shirt is basically worth my perceived value – what I believe it is worth, and therefore, willing to pay for it! The fact is how much consumers are willing to pay is affected by what goes on in their head. Behavioural Decision scientists, Behavioural Economists and Price Psychologists have studied how prices work to influence people’s actions for many years. Consumers make decisions to buy or not to buy based on cues. Furthermore, people don’t really know how much something should cost because nothing has a fixed monetary value. Consequently, the same price may be seen as a bargain or over-the-top, depending on the context. The time has come for small businesses to start using the available knowledge to their advantage so they can maximise sales and profitability.
/making-sure-the-price-is-right.author: EnyOsung

/google-bing-mobile-friendly-ratings-exp.title: Google & Bing Mobile-Friendly Ratings Explained
/google-bing-mobile-friendly-ratings-exp.description: Learn about the impact of Google's mobile-friendly algorithm update and how it affects website rankings on mobile search. Discover the importance of mobile-friendliness and how it influences the user experience. Find out how both Google and Bing use mobile-friendly labels to inform mobile searchers about the quality of websites. Understand the criteria for mobile-friendliness and the factors that search engines consider when ranking mobile websites. Gain insights into testing for mobile-friendliness and strategies to improve your website's visibility and rankings on mobile search results.
/google-bing-mobile-friendly-ratings-exp.p: Are you curious about the impact of Google's mobile-friendly algorithm update and how it can affect your website's rankings on mobile search? Understanding the importance of mobile-friendliness and its influence on the user experience is crucial in today's digital landscape. Both Google and Bing utilize mobile-friendly labels to help mobile searchers identify high-quality websites. So, what criteria do search engines consider when ranking mobile websites? How can you test for mobile-friendliness and improve your website's visibility and rankings on mobile search results? Let's dive in!
/google-bing-mobile-friendly-ratings-exp.p2: With Google's algorithm update, having a mobile-friendly website has become essential. It directly impacts your website's rankings on mobile search, ensuring that users have a seamless experience. This update, often dubbed as mobile apocalypse or mobilegeddon, emphasizes the significance of catering to mobile users. It's not just Google; Bing also incorporates mobile-friendly labels to guide mobile searchers towards websites that offer an optimized mobile experience. To meet the criteria for mobile-friendliness, your website should focus on a few key factors. First and foremost, responsive design is crucial. This means your website adapts and functions smoothly across various screen sizes and devices. Additionally, easy navigation and readable text are essential for users to engage with your content effortlessly. Optimizing page speed is another important aspect, as slow-loading websites can frustrate users and lead to higher bounce rates. Testing your website for mobile-friendliness is a great way to gauge its performance. Tools like Google's Mobile-Friendly Test and mobile usability reports in Google Webmaster Tools can provide valuable insights. By analyzing the results, you can identify areas for improvement and make necessary adjustments to enhance the mobile experience. Improving your website's visibility and rankings on mobile search results requires a strategic approach. Start by ensuring your content is unique, relevant, and valuable to users. Providing a great experience across all devices is crucial, so focus on compatibility, readability, and functionality. It's also worth considering a responsive website design, which automatically adjusts to fit any screen size and offers a consistent experience. Moreover, make sure search engine bots can easily crawl your site without any barriers, such as blocked JavaScript or CSS files.
/google-bing-mobile-friendly-ratings-exp.p3: By prioritizing mobile-friendliness and implementing these strategies, you can boost your website's visibility and rankings on mobile search results. This way, you'll capture the attention of the ever-growing number of mobile users, improve user engagement, and drive more traffic to your site. Remember, adapting to the mobile-friendly landscape is not just about appeasing search engines; it's about creating a seamless experience for your users. So, take the necessary steps to optimize your website for mobile devices, and watch your online presence thrive in the mobile search arena!
/google-bing-mobile-friendly-ratings-exp.author: EnyOsung

/small-business-marketing-pitfalls-a-met.p: Discover the pitfalls that many small business owners fall into, especially when it comes to marketing their business. Limited resources often make it challenging to find the budget for marketing experts. As a result, small businesses often decide to make marketing everyone's job, which can lead to struggles in attracting enough customers. The team may start murmuring about needing more help, and desperate appeals for resources become relentless clamor. While caring entrepreneurs try to provide additional resources, such as books or training, these are often short-term fixes. The cycle continues as the team realizes that better marketing could transform the business into a thriving company. However, expecting non-marketing staff to achieve expert-level marketing results is unrealistic. Taking responsibility for marketing oneself may seem like a viable option, but it often leads to a lack of time, knowledge, and effective content creation. This DIY approach perpetuates the cycle of murmurs, nagging, and desperate appeals for expert marketing. Smallbiz-emarketing believes there is a better way. Their professional digital marketing services can help small businesses save time, money, and mental well-being. By providing expert help within a limited budget, they enable businesses to focus on what they do best while attracting target customers. Discover a new approach to marketing and leave behind the pitfalls of the vicious cycle.
